greeting: Greetings from The On-Line Encyclopedia of Integer Sequences! http://oeis.org/

results.name: Odd part of phi(n): a(n) = A000265(A000010(n)).
comment: This is not necessarily the squarefree kernel. E.g., for n=19, phi(19)=18 is divisible by 9, an odd square. Values at which this kernel is 1 correspond to A003401 (polygons constructible with ruler and compass).
Multiplicative with a(2^e) = 1, a(p^e) = p^(e-1)*A000265(p-1). - _Christian G. Bower_, May 16 2005
link: Reinhard Zumkeller, Table of n, a(n) for n = 1..10000
formula: Let n" be the odd part of n, S be the odd squarefree kernel of n and p_i {i = 1..z} be all the prime factors of S. Then the sequence can be constructed by the following:
a(n) = (n-1)" when n is prime; and
a(n) = Product_{i = 1..z} a(p_i)*n"/S when n is composite (see Examples).
a(n) = A336466(n) for squarefree n (see A005117).
example: n = 70 = 2*5*7, phi(70) = 24 = 8*3, so the odd kernel of phi(70) is a(70)=3. [corrected by _Bob Selcoe_, Aug 22 2017]
mathematica: Array[NestWhile[Ceiling[#/2] &, EulerPhi@ #, EvenQ] &, 94] (* _Michael De Vlieger_, Aug 22 2017 *) (* or *)
results.author: _Labos Elemer_, Jan 18 2000
